questions.question_text:
A network engineer is implementing a QoS policy for outbound management traffic classification and marking on a CPE device with these requirements:
✑ Management protocols must be marked with DSCP AF class 2 with low drop probability.
✑ Monitoring protocols must be marked with DSCP AF class 1 with low drop probability.
✑ All remaining traffic must be marked with a DSCP value of 0.
Which configuration must the engineer implement to satisfy the requirements?

choices.C: policy-map cpe-mgmt-policy class management set ip dscp af23 class monitoring set ip dscp af13 class class-default set ip dscp default end
choices.B: policy-map cpe-mgmt-policy class management set ip dscp af21 class monitoring set ip dscp af11 class class-default set ip dscp af0 end
choices.D: policy-map cpe-mgmt-policy class management set ip dscp af23 class monitoring set ip dscp af13 class class-default set ip dscp af0 end
choices.A: policy-map cpe-mgmt-policy class management set ip dscp af21 class monitoring set ip dscp af11 class class-default set ip dscp default end

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A is correct. 
af10 as far as I can tell does not exist. Options B and D are eliminated.
af23 has high drop probability. Option C is eliminated
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/nexus1000/sw/4_0/qos/configuration/guide/nexus1000v_qos/qos_6dscp_val.pdf

Selected Answer: A
A is correct.
Set default value of DSCP is 0, which is 'Best Effort'.
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/quality-of-service-qos/qos-packet-marking/10103-dscpvalues.html

Selected Answer: A
definitely A

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

Option A is correct
Default value of DSCP is 'Best Effort' which has value of '0'
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/nexus1000/sw/4_0/qos/configuration/guide/nexus1000v_qos/qos_6dscp_val.pdf
Correct answer is A

comments.content: Yes, it's A, coz all remaining traffic must be marked with a DSCP value of 0, and this is default and not af10

choices.C: A data and default MDT are created to flood the multicast stream out of all PIM-SM neighbors.
choices.B: A data MDT is created to if it is a (*, G) multicast route entries.
choices.D: A data MDT is created to allow for the best transmission through the core for (S, G) multicast route entries.
choices.A: The traffic uses the default MDT to transmit the data only if it is a (S, G) multicast route entry.

questions.question_text: What occurs when a high bandwidth multicast stream is sent over an MVPN using Cisco hardware?

comments.content:
I think it's A
MVPN establishes a static default MDT for each multicast domain. The default MDT defines the path used by PE routers to send multicast data and control messages to every other PE router in the multicast domain.
--------------------------------------------------
Data MDTs are created only for (S, G) multicast route entries within the VRF multicast routing table. They are not created for (*, G) entries regardless of the value of the individual source data rate.


https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/ipmulti_mvpn/configuration/xe-3s/imc-mvpn-xe-3s-book/imc_cfg_mc_vpn.html#GUID-60B1EC78-3A10-447E-BEBE-9F076511FBCB

D is correct, I could only find the reference in jefranca's doc, it states crearly what you said.
MDTs are not created for (*, G) entries.

discussion.content: According to the doc at https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/ipmulti_mvpn/configuration/xe-3s/imc-mvpn-xe-3s-book/imc_cfg_mc_vpn.html#GUID-60B1EC78-3A10-447E-BEBE-9F076511FBCB Data MDTs are created only for (S, G) multicast route entries within the VRF multicast routing table. They are not created for (*, G) entries regardless of the value of the individual source data rate. So D is correct.

comments.content:
sorry wrong 1
thejag 1 year ago
D is correct:

Data MDT is for "hight-bandwidth transmissions":

MVPN supports two MDT types:

•Default MDT—The default MDT is a permanent channel for PIM control messages and low-bandwidth streams between all PE routers in a particular multicast domain. All multicast traffic in the default MDT is replicated to every other PE router in the domain. Each PE router is logically seen as a PIM neighbor (one hop away) from every other PE router in the domain.

•Data MDT—Data MDTs are optional. If enabled, they are dynamically created to provide optimal paths for high-bandwidth transmissions, such as full-motion video, that do not need to be sent to every PE router. This allows for on-demand forwarding of high-bandwidth traffic between PE routers, so as to avoid flooding every PE router with every high-bandwidth stream that might be created.

Data MDT is for "hight-bandwidth transmissions":

MVPN supports two MDT types:

•Default MDT—The default MDT is a permanent channel for PIM control messages and low-bandwidth streams between all PE routers in a particular multicast domain. All multicast traffic in the default MDT is replicated to every other PE router in the domain. Each PE router is logically seen as a PIM neighbor (one hop away) from every other PE router in the domain.

•Data MDT—Data MDTs are optional. If enabled, they are dynamically created to provide optimal paths for high-bandwidth transmissions, such as full-motion video, that do not need to be sent to every PE router. This allows for on-demand forwarding of high-bandwidth traffic between PE routers, so as to avoid flooding every PE router with every high-bandwidth stream that might be created.

questions.question_text: An engineer is implementing IGMP with SSM on a multicampus network that supports video streaming. Which task must the engineer perform as part of the process?

discussion.content:
Answer is correct:

IGMPv3 is defined in RFC 3376 and then updated by RFC 4604. The main improvement IGMPv3 has, when compared with IGMPv2, is the support for Source-Specific Multicasting (SSM).
i agree with D

choices.D: Configure Cisco MPLS TE for use with E-TREE.
choices.A: Configure QoS for MPLS and E-ACCESS.

questions.question_text: An engineer must extend Layer 2 between two campus sites connected through an MPLS backbone that encapsulates Layer 2 and Layer 3 data. Which action must the engineer perform on the routers to accomplish this task?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Answer : 
A. Configure QoS for MPLS and E-ACCESS: This involves quality of service settings and is not directly related to extending Layer 2 over MPLS.
B. Configure a EtherChannel for E-LAN: EtherChannel is used for bundling multiple physical links into a single logical link, not for extending Layer 2 across an MPLS backbone.
C. Configure a pseudowire for E-LINE: This is the correct method. A pseudowire provides a virtual point-to-point connection over an MPLS network, supporting Layer 2 extension.
D. Configure Cisco MPLS TE for use with E-TREE: MPLS Traffic Engineering (TE) is used for optimizing the path selection in an MPLS network, and E-TREE is a different service type. This is not the correct action for extending Layer 2 between two sites.

questions.question_text: Which statement describes the advantage of a Multi-Layer control plane?

discussion.content: I think C is the correct answer in this question. There is is nothing about multivendor config capabilities in multi layer control plane.

There is nothing with "multivendor" and nothing with "layer 0 Wavelenght restoration"
I think "B" is the correct anwser!

comments.content: Got this Question in Exam. C is correct not B.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Answer B: "It automatically provisions, monitors, and manages traffic across Layer 0 to Layer 3."

A Multi-Layer control plane can help automate network management tasks across multiple layers of the OSI model, including Layer 0 (physical layer) to Layer 3 (network layer). By automating these tasks, network administrators can reduce the risk of human error and improve network reliability.

comments.content:
Cisco documents what layer 0 is here:

https://www.cisco.com/c/dam/global/shared/assets/pdf/ncs4000-platform.pdf

I agree with you, it's C

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
WOW, this question is so obscure and for sure is not covered in the Cisco official training material. These links may help make some sense of it, I learned something new: 

I think the answer is indeed C based on this:

https://orhanergun.net/what-is-layer-0-in-the-osi-layers - "If you are working in transport networking, you already know that Layer 0 is the photonics layer, more specifically, DWDM is considered as the Layer 0 of the OSI layers."

https://www.acgcc.com/media/reports/files/Cisco-nLight-Economics-Whitepaper_ACG.pdf - "nLight optimizes the network, providing protection via the IP layer and restoration via the optical layer"

This is probably the most debated question and I see why.
I checked all the links provided here, and I still come to the conclusion A is the correct answer.
If this is in regards to the OSI layer model , there is no such thing as layer 0 , therefore I go with answer A.
Please prove me wrong.

comments.content:
the best thing I found as a reference was this link back in 2014
notice it does mention multi vendors

discussion.content: All question about WDM/OTN, Cisco formulates them wrong. Multi-layer control plane is the combination for both IP and OTN network management. One could consider all things optical as layer 0, which would exclude answer 'A'. 'B' mentions automatically provisioning which is a big statement but could be considered right. If 'dynamic wavelength restoration' means ability to geographically protect an OTN service then this is right.

The multi-layer aspect
refers to the fact end-to-end service may be instantiated via a
data plane path which traverses multiple different network
elements that belong to different technology layers.
I'd vote for 'C'
i think A is correct: https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/collateral/switches/catalyst-3750-series-switches/whitepaper_c11-718852.html

choices.D: It minimizes human error configuring converged networks.
choices.C: It supports dynamic wavelength restoration in Layer 0.
choices.A: It provides multivendor configuration capabilities for Layer 3 to Layer 1.
choices.B: It automatically provisions, monitors, and manages traffic across Layer 0 to Layer 3.
